message: I'll be taking my 5DmkII and taking photos/vids of the conference
mini interviews will be posted to the changelog!
Ok - Vern has been looking for people to cover some posters w/ maybe flip video.
Talk about 'em here!
Videos of PyCon talks has been nice, now I'd like to encourage informal community videos during the conference.
See a cool thing going on?   Grab your Android / iPhone / etc.  and try to video stream it (I use qik.com - share on twitter if you like).
If you get something good, and it generates buzz here during the conference - all the better!
Maybe we can get pizza & beer (or something) to the best viral videos during the conference (I think we can)
@yarkot It's probably too late this year, but it seems like PyDocumentary would be a good thing next year.
@kennethreitz Awesome hook up with me on Sunday before the poster session

I'm going to take short, streaming (posted "live") videos as much as I can, every time I see - people gathering having fun,  volunteers, etc.   qik.com - try it before the conference to figure out how to use it best w/ your phone.
I'll bring my xacti along, will 960x540 be enough or should we aim higher? I have no idea of how to "stream". Perhaps someone will explain.
Well - it will suck people's batteries, so "viral" is to encourage people to share interesting (and expectedly brief) moments. I'm going to try a video interview with @holdenweb, for starters :-)

As a point of ref: I first saw qik.com when they had broadcasts from a web conference in England a few years ago, and people were broadcasting simultaneously from tutorials (i.e. a dozen at a time, per room) and you could watch the presentation live - with all the angles of presenter, and people asking questions, whiteboards, etc. (pick your view).   I don't know what they did special (if anything) to handle it, but there were hundreds of simultaneous feeds from that.
yea, a lot of short-form videos would be more exciting in my mind.  Also it makes them much easier to upload and catalog ;)

@jkelkar:  sign up for an account on qik.com (sort of like a picasa for low-res videos);  download picasa app to your cell phone;   from your phone - qik / aim / shoot:  posted to your videos live.   (you can make the stream private or public).   Then share thru twitter, etc.
The videos are stored on your qik account, like pictures, but appear "live" (more or less, within usually some dozens of seconds).

I wonder what dozens of people streaming to qik (or others) will do to the wifi network as that will probably be what most of the phones end up using since it's available.  Wouldn't it be more network friendly if people record locally and then upload after?

Maybe - but I post thru my non-wifi.   If people set their phones to wifi, and it jams the airwaves, it will for anything - mail notifications, tweets, etc. on their phones.   qik is relatively low res, so perfect for viral.
But no doubt it will do something.
I just don't expect (with ~1500 other uses) that a dozen of these at any given instance will be noticable;  hundreds - yes, I'll bet we'll feel it.

cool - I admit I was speaking from a lack of concrete examples, so your report of it working well from that web conference is very encouraging.  Having a large number of views and angles will be very interesting to view/experience
they're all uploaded as you record - so sharing (or not) would be all you'd need to do.  For a "best viral videos from pycon" it would just take someone linking to these.
